text: Choose the correct sentence (0).
explanation: The correct sentence uses proper subject-verb agreement.

choices.text: Each of the students have a book.
Each of the students has a book.
Each of the students are having a book.
Each of the student have books.

text: Choose the correct sentence (2).
explanation: The correct sentence avoids double negatives.

choices.text: He didn’t do nothing about the problem.
He didn’t do anything about the problem.
He don’t do nothing about the problem.
He doesn’t did anything about the problem.

text: Choose the correct sentence (3).
explanation: The correct sentence uses the proper verb tense.

choices.text: She has finish her report yesterday.
She finished her report yesterday.
She has finished her report yesterday.
She finishing her report yesterday.

text: Choose the correct sentence (4).
explanation: The correct sentence uses the correct pronoun agreement.

choices.text: Everyone must bring their own ID.
Everyone must bring his or her own ID.
Everyone must bring theirselves ID.
Everyone must brings their ID.

text: Choose the correct sentence (5).
explanation: The correct sentence uses proper comparison form.

choices.text: This problem is more easier than the last one.
This problem is easier than the last one.
This problem is most easier than the last one.
This problem is easy than the last one.

text: Choose the correct sentence (6).
explanation: The correct sentence uses the correct preposition.

choices.text: She is married with a doctor.
She is married to a doctor.
She is married by a doctor.
She is married from a doctor.

text: Choose the correct sentence (7).
explanation: The correct sentence avoids redundancy.

choices.text: They returned back to the office early.
They returned to the office early.
They back returned to the office early.
They returned again back to the office.

text: Choose the correct sentence (8).
explanation: The correct sentence uses correct subject-verb agreement with compound subjects.

choices.text: Bread and butter are his favorite breakfast.
Bread and butter is his favorite breakfast.
Bread and butter were his favorite breakfast.
Bread and butter have his favorite breakfast.

text: Choose the correct sentence (9).
explanation: The correct sentence uses the correct form of the verb after 'did'.

choices.text: She did not knew the answer.
She did not know the answer.
She did not known the answer.
She did not knowing the answer.

text: Choose the correct sentence (10).
explanation: The correct sentence uses proper capitalization and punctuation.

choices.text: my father works in manila.
My father works in Manila.
My Father works in manila.
my Father works in Manila.

text: Which sentence is grammatically correct?
explanation: The correct sentence avoids a dangling modifier by clearly stating who performed the action.

choices.text: Walking down the street, the wallet was found by Maria.
Walking down the street, Maria found a wallet.
The wallet was found while walking down the street by Maria.
While walking, the street revealed a wallet to Maria.

text: Choose the sentence with correct parallel structure.
explanation: Parallel structure requires items in a list to follow the same grammatical form.

choices.text: She enjoys reading, to jog, and swimming.
She enjoys reading, jogging, and swimming.
She enjoys to read, jogging, and swims.
She enjoys reading, jog, and to swim.

text: Which sentence contains a grammatical error?
explanation: The subject 'each' is singular and requires a singular verb.

choices.text: Each of the employees is required to attend.
Everyone knows the policy.
The team meets every Friday.
Each of the applicants are qualified.

text:
Fill in the blank with the correct word.
Neither of the answers _____ correct.
explanation: The subject 'neither' is singular, so it takes a singular verb.

choices.text: are
were
is
have been

text: Which sentence is grammatically correct?
explanation: The correct sentence properly places the modifier next to the word it describes.

choices.text: After reading the report, the meeting was canceled.
After reading the report, the manager canceled the meeting.
The meeting was canceled after reading the report.
After the report was read, canceling the meeting.

text: Choose the sentence that demonstrates correct parallelism.
explanation: All items in a series must follow the same grammatical form.

choices.text: He likes to cook, jogging, and swims.
He likes cooking, jogging, and swimming.
He likes to cook, jogging, and to swim.
He likes cooking, jog, and to swim.

text: Which sentence uses the idiom correctly?
explanation: ‘On the same page’ means to agree or share the same understanding.

choices.text: They are on the same page of the book.
The team is on the same page about the project goals.
They turned the same page yesterday.
They wrote on the same page together.

text: Which sentence contains an error in verb tense?
explanation: The sentence incorrectly shifts verb tense.

choices.text: She finished her work and went home.
He was reading when the phone rang.
They have completed the task already.
He entered the room and is sitting down.

text:
Fill in the blank with the correct word.
The number of applicants _____ increased this year.
explanation: ‘The number’ is treated as a singular subject.

choices.text: have
are
has
were

text: Which sentence avoids ambiguity?
explanation: The correct sentence clearly states who performed the action.

choices.text: She told her sister that she was promoted.
She told her sister about her promotion.
She told her sister she got promoted.
She said she was promoted to her sister.

text: Which sentence correctly uses subject-verb agreement?
explanation: Collective nouns may be treated as singular when acting as a unit.

choices.text: The jury are divided in their opinion.
The jury is divided in its opinion.
The jury were deciding its verdict.
The jury have reached its decision.

text: Choose the sentence with correct use of comparison.
explanation: Comparatives are used when comparing two items.

choices.text: Of the two designs, this is the most attractive.
Of the two designs, this is the more attractive.
Of the two designs, this is the attractive one.
Of the two designs, this is attractiver.

text: Which sentence contains a misplaced modifier?
explanation: The modifier is incorrectly placed, making the sentence unclear.

choices.text: Running quickly, the finish line came into view.
Running quickly, the athlete saw the finish line.
The athlete ran quickly toward the finish line.
The finish line came into view as the athlete ran.

text: Which sentence correctly uses an idiomatic expression?
explanation: ‘In the long run’ refers to a long-term outcome.

choices.text: In the long run of the marathon, he won.
In the long run, saving money will benefit her.
In the long running, he improved his skills.
In the longest run, the plan will work.

text: Which sentence is grammatically correct?
explanation: The phrase 'as well as' does not make the subject plural.

choices.text: The manager, as well as the employees, are attending the meeting.
The manager, as well as the employees, is attending the meeting.
The manager and the employees is attending the meeting.
The manager with the employees are attending the meeting.

text: Which sentence uses correct subject-verb agreement?
explanation: ‘A number of’ takes a plural verb, while ‘the number of’ takes a singular verb.

choices.text: A number of applicants has submitted their forms.
A number of applicants have submitted their forms.
The number of applicants have increased.
The number of applicants are increasing.

text: Which sentence avoids faulty comparison?
explanation: Comparisons must be logically equivalent.

choices.text: Her salary is higher than any employee in the company.
Her salary is higher than that of any other employee in the company.
Her salary is higher than any other employee.
Her salary is higher than all employees.

text: Which sentence is logically and grammatically correct?
explanation: The comparison must exclude the subject being compared.

choices.text: He is more qualified than anyone in the applicants.
He is more qualified than any other applicant.
He is more qualified than all applicants.
He is the most qualified than the others.

text: Which sentence correctly uses the word 'only'?
explanation: Misplacing 'only' changes the meaning of the sentence.

choices.text: She only said she would help her sister.
She said she would help only her sister.
Only she said she would help her sister.
She said only she would help her sister.

text: Which sentence is free from ambiguity?
explanation: The sentence clearly identifies who owns the object.

choices.text: Maria spoke to Ana about her promotion.
Maria spoke to Ana about Maria’s promotion.
Maria spoke about her promotion to Ana.
Maria told Ana she was promoted.

text: Which sentence correctly applies the rule on correlative conjunctions?
explanation: Verbs must agree with the subject closest to them.

choices.text: Either the teachers or the principal are responsible.
Either the teachers or the principal is responsible.
Either the principal or the teachers is responsible.
Either the principal or the teachers was responsible.

text: Which sentence avoids illogical construction?
explanation: Abstract ideas cannot logically perform physical actions.

choices.text: His explanation convinced the committee.
He convinced the committee with his explanation.
The explanation persuaded the members.
The idea argued against the proposal.

text: Which sentence correctly uses a conditional statement?
explanation: The verb tenses must match the condition being expressed.

choices.text: If she will study harder, she would pass.
If she studied harder, she would pass.
If she studies harder, she would have passed.
If she had studied harder, she will pass.

text: Which sentence is logically sound?
explanation: A sentence must not contradict itself.

choices.text: The meeting was postponed to an earlier date.
The meeting was rescheduled to a later date.
The meeting was delayed ahead of time.
The meeting was advanced after the deadline.

text: Which sentence is grammatically correct?
explanation: The phrase 'as well as' does not make the subject plural.

choices.text: The manager, as well as the employees, are attending the meeting.
The manager, as well as the employees, is attending the meeting.
The manager and the employees is attending the meeting.
The manager with the employees are attending the meeting.

text: Which sentence uses correct subject-verb agreement?
explanation: ‘A number of’ takes a plural verb, while ‘the number of’ takes a singular verb.

choices.text: A number of applicants has submitted their forms.
A number of applicants have submitted their forms.
The number of applicants have increased.
The number of applicants are increasing.

explanation: Comparisons must be logically equivalent.

choices.text: Her salary is higher than any employee in the company.
Her salary is higher than that of any other employee in the company.
Her salary is higher than any other employee.
Her salary is higher than all employees.

text: Which sentence is logically and grammatically correct?
explanation: The comparison must exclude the subject being compared.

choices.text: He is more qualified than anyone in the applicants.
He is more qualified than any other applicant.
He is more qualified than all applicants.
He is the most qualified than the others.

explanation: Misplacing 'only' changes the meaning of the sentence.

choices.text: She only said she would help her sister.
She said she would help only her sister.
Only she said she would help her sister.
She said only she would help her sister.

explanation: The sentence clearly identifies who owns the object.

choices.text: Maria spoke to Ana about her promotion.
Maria spoke to Ana about Maria’s promotion.
Maria spoke about her promotion to Ana.
Maria told Ana she was promoted.

explanation: Verbs must agree with the subject closest to them.

choices.text: Either the teachers or the principal are responsible.
Either the teachers or the principal is responsible.
Either the principal or the teachers is responsible.
Either the principal or the teachers was responsible.

explanation: Abstract ideas cannot logically perform physical actions.

choices.text: His explanation convinced the committee.
He convinced the committee with his explanation.
The explanation persuaded the members.
The idea argued against the proposal.

explanation: The verb tenses must match the condition being expressed.

choices.text: If she will study harder, she would pass.
If she studied harder, she would pass.
If she studies harder, she would have passed.

explanation: A sentence must not contradict itself.

choices.text: The meeting was postponed to an earlier date.
The meeting was rescheduled to a later date.
